subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Digest Number 621
msgSnippet: I have come to more strongly prefer un-distinguishing vowels (at least to some degree) the more I have read postings from this group!  :^) How about, to help
messageBody:
I have come to more strongly prefer "un-distinguishing" vowels (at least to some degree) the more I have read postings from this group!  :^)

How about, to help prevent some of the below problems, using
an "Å/å" analog if it is officially spelled "A" but at times pronounced "O,"
and an "Ô/ô" (or "Ø/ø") analog if spelled "O" but pronounced "A,"
"Œ/œ" and "Æ/æ" can be for the O>E & A>E mergers,
and "A" "E" & "O" > "U" ("uh") mergers could be "Ǎ/ǎ" "Ě/ě" & "Ǒ/ǒ"
(These would eliminate most bare uses of  "a, e, o".)

Thought exercises...


> I've long felt that any reformed spelling system
> for English with international intentions should
> simply disregard to distinguish TRAP-BATH-
> PALM/FATHER, LOT-CLOTH-THOUGHT and NORTH-FORCE
> respectively. 

Three objections (all of which you discuss, but which seem to me
jointly overwhelming) :

1) It creates too much homonymy;

2) It puts LOT on the wrong side of the divide for
some two-thirds of all native speakers (all of the
U.S. except Eastern New England, and all of Canada);

3) It deviates too far from the spirit of QS, which is
"RP plus rhoticism".
